commentBody:
Fantastic!

I think this puzzle has a few layers of fun....

If you know the headlines because you just kinda know the dates...And immediately know what the topic has to be...That's one of the levels of fun.

A second is that you can solve them and theyre are just kinda fun things to learn.

And then there is Headless Body in Topless Bar...and really...There aint nothing better than that.

84A [Headwear that's stereotypically red]:

Hands up if you thought MAGA HAT???

Second attempt:

84: [Headwear that's stereotypically red]

Hands up if your mind went first to a certain recent ball cap that's been in the news in the past decade or so?!?!

"I've read more newspapers than anyone else!"
"Yeah, you're in the lede!"

(I'm headline over heels for these puns.)

These got surprisingly harder after Nixon resigned - I took forever to get the right thing to drop dead! Laughing all the way!

To make up for my sluggish performance, here are some extra ‚Äúextra extra‚Äùs that seem au courant to me:

CASSANDRA FOR THE WIN
GREED SEETHES
DAYSHIFT HOTLINE

Hey Michael, inquiring minds want to know, what were your other images aside from your terrific TITANIC SINKS one???




Et tu, emu.
This was a HARD puzzle, with a natick for me where SAL and SNEAD crossed. What is SAL soda?

Just what we need ‚Äî scary headlines!

Kidding, of course.  I enjoyed this news-based puzzle and don‚Äôt recall seeing a similar theme before.  My first comment was emubargoed, so perhaps if I‚Äôm a bit more discreet this one will get through. 

Possible recent headline:  11/5/2024
DEMOCRACY SINKS

Great theme that I quickly caught on to. With 3 of the headlines coming from NYC papers, I‚Äôve seen reproductions frequently. The only one I wasn‚Äôt familiar with was the one from Variety, but knew it referred to the stock market crash. It was an odd case of the theme entries helping with some of the crosses rather than the other way around.

about 90 across: Let's not confuse health CARE and health INSURANCE. 

Insurers provide no care (and as too many of us know, they often are an impediment to actual care).

Nice crossword, but hardly a puzzle for me. YMMV. 

I entered most of the themers straight from the clues; one or two needed a crossing letter or two to be sure. After that, the Tuesday-level-clued fill fell fast. And with GAR and GREED already in place, I had FIREHAT first FORTHEWIN. There were a few nice touches in the fill, but not enough to keep me happy through a 21x21. Get me rewrite.
REALLY struggled with the obscurity of some of today‚Äôs cluing. While I‚Äôm on the younger side, I imagine some of these references were challenging even when they were timely.

Loved how those old classic headlines were worked into this -- but I bet younger solvers felt like I do when faced with coming up with the name of a popular group or song from the last few years. 

With almost everyone getting news on -line in one way or another -- will we ever have such shared headlines again?
The most difficult Sunday we've had in the past few weeks. I didn't have much fun completing it, to be honest, but I did enjoy the challenge. (Or "enjoy," I suppose I should say. *Appreciate.*)

Started out easy, but had a hard time parsing FORDTOCITYDROPDEAD and never heard of the delightful HEADLESS‚Ä¶. I don‚Äôt know the HBCU initials although I knew the colleges so had trouble with C-ED and kept having CCED in my brain. Finally never heard of SAL soda and can‚Äôt spell SNEAD so had to flyspeck that. No complaints, all on me, and had fun learning those headlines.

The Carolina Reaper is a CHILE (with an E), not CHILI (which is the stew).

Just sayin‚Äô ‚Ä¶
After solving this one, if anyone would like to try the Sunday Crossword from 50 years ago... https://www.xwordinfo.com/Solve?psdate=3/9/1975

All the headlines were familiar to me with the exception of WALL ST LAYS AN EGG. I remember well the HEADLESS BODY IN TOPLESS BAR headline. It was classic NY Post, a tabloid paper well known for sensational headlines that are often hysterically funny (and punny). They had a field day when NY Congressman Anthony Weiner was exposed in a salacious scandal (exposed being an operative word). 

Great word APOCRYPHA, and a fun clue for PORCH (‚ÄúWhere people typically go to the mat‚Äù). 

Don't forget to spring ahead.

Okay hands up if you are both old and never heard the term "sal soda".  (I'd heard washing soda.)  Obviously in order for this to matter one also requires a poor grasp of the spelling of Sal Snead's name.  :)

Decent enough puzzle.  I wonder if I would have liked it better with the original illustrations.  Big honking sinks sound like a hoot, and the "famous dates" thing has been done to death here....

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)
Twice my normal time due to a long term commitment to ‚ÄúDALEYDEFEATSTRUMAN‚Äù‚Ä¶ I guess the Chicago paper messed up my brain.
Terrible. I guess it's just me. I don't get the jokes, can't make sense of the clues. I am looking for something to engage my very bored mind and I don't find it here.
Tough.
My first job was carrying typeface down to the basement where the pieces were laud and headlines made
Gerald Ford did not lose the nomination in 1976, though he was challenged by future nominee Ronald Reagan. But he lost the general election to Jimmy Carter.

Being a news junkie until roughly four months ago, I didn‚Äôt have any trouble with this one. The classic NY Post headline reminded me of a scene from The Critic, a 90s cartoon canceled way too soon: https://youtu.be/wBjVzG4u9FU
"Headless Body" is the greatest headline, followed by "Harvard Beats Yale 29-29."
Not a great puzzle. Have seen far better from NYT.

Oh my. 

As soon as I figured out the theme, I knew I had no chance as I lack the histories. Still I enjoyed finding out interesting headlines along the way, but‚Ä¶

I found some words either too obscure and/or awkward for me, some I didn‚Äôt understand even after the answer.  So went the Sunday struggle.

One of my favorite headlines ever occurred in the Philadelphia Daily News in connection with an investigation into a number of human heads found in boxes.  ‚ÄúEars Found In Probe Of Heads.‚Äù  Not as famous perhaps as the ones in Sunday‚Äôs puzzle, but worth a (gruesome) chuckle.

Tonight was another instance of puzzle and music synchronicity for me.  Within minutes of plugging in SENOR for 59A Chick Corea‚Äôs and Gary Burton‚Äôs delightful SENOR Mouse popped up on the playlist that I was listening to. The album, Crystal Silence, on which Senor Mouse appears is a shimmering delight from start to finish.
@Caitlin - Ford did not lose his party‚Äôs nomination in 1976.  He lost the general election to Carter.
I remember reading somewhere that ‚ÄúHeadless Body‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Äù was the best example of a NY Post headline except for one thing.   It was accurate.

Thanks to my kids' enjoyment of Phineas and Ferb, I'll never forget what an aglet is. 
Hard ish puzzle for me. Til what sal soda is. And that Sosa isn't the only Slammin' Sammy. 
Always loved the "Headless..." headline.
Loved the challenge!  A few really tough ones for me, but nothing that I couldn't figure out with a little time and thought.

Very happy to redeem myself with this puzzle after failing miserably to solve yesterday's. The headlines helped, even the HEADLESS BODY IN TOPLESS BAR which I'd never seen but given the source figured out once I had enough crosses.
I was shocked to discover that Mr. Schlossberg is actually from Bend!  I'm glad I decided to look at the puzzle today because I don't very often.
I loved, loved, loved this puzzle. It helps that I'd heard of all the headlines.

Great puzzle! 

I enjoy wordplay Sundays but I also really enjoy when a puzzle like this tickles a different part of the brain. I wasn't aware of the Ford to City headline, that's an incredible story.

As for the New York Post, one I kept for my collection: a nifty bit of copywriting after Paul McCartney revealed that the Beatles had engaged in a group activity which is more commonly solo. The headline: 'Beat the Meatles!'
Good theme, but the middle one was lost on me. Had WALLST, but couldn't get LAYSANEGG No idea what SAL soda is, never heard of Louis MALLE or a GAR fish
Phew. After a relatively easy Thu, Fri and Sat this week, that was one solid workout!
Jesus Christ. RIP my streak.
Didn't know what an HBCU was and 'topless car' seemed perfect.
Very difficult, very fun puzzle. Heard a few clues or answers for the first time, and they really got me stuck for a minute.

Really, really enjoyed this walk thorough history.  I've was here for many of them, though not the Titanic.  And technically not the Wall Street egg laying, although IMO Wall Street embarrasses the bejesus out of itself simply by being Wall Street.

My heart was in my mouth when I saw 84A[Headwear that's stereotypically red].  

I wonder if we're entering a whole new world of trolling.

Now that I've read through the comments, I must say I'm surprised that people found this hard.

It is true that I'm a news junkie, but maybe I've underestimated the extent of the infection.  When I saw 27A[The New York Times, 8/9/1974] I immediately filled in NIXONRESIGNS.   I don't think I had a cross, but if I did and it didn't agree I'd have gotten rid of it.

The only problem I had with 39A is that I was thinking the verb was "beats" rather than "defeats".

There was no way I would ever solve this.

There were just too many things I simply did not know (so many names!), and also loads of clues and answers I don't understand even now, having revealed them.

I usually ask the community here to explain stuff I didn't get, but today there was just so much of it I just don't have it in me to find it all in the huge grid and write down here. Some quick examples: SAL soda? HBCU (and its clue)? 

I haven't failed that badly in several weeks. HEADLESS BODY IN TOPLESS BAR is what I feel like after today's "solve" ü§™

. . . but there is one in "BILL": it's right in the center, and usually spelled with a capital letter.

(As I often remind my co-workers.)

The photo of a linotype operator reminded me that my Dad told me he had a part-time job after school as a "printer's devil," one who assists the linotypist with "mixing tubs of ink and fetching type." ( https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Printer%27s_devil#:~:text=A%20printer's%20devil%20was%20a,of%20ink%20and%20fetching%20type. ) He always came home from that job tired and covered in ink. The answer to 89D reminded me of my Dad's mother, who often used that expression, and I can still hear Granny saying it, always preceded by "Well, ..." in my mind's ear. Thank you to Michael Schlossberg for an enjoyable puzzle and, for me, an enjoyable trip down Memory Lane.
Interesting interpretation of both "For The Win" and "Modern Lingo"

Absolutely brutal. The last headline was particularly rough, and I have to say I‚Äôve never heard of OLMEC, TOSCANINI, MALLE, AGLET, LADED, SAL soda, APOCRYPHA, YARD glass, PARSONS, Bel PAESE, Joe TYNAN, HBCU, IDA McKinley, HOSTA, UPICE, OAS, or Sammy SNEAD. Not quite sure whose wheelhouse these would all be in, but safe to say it‚Äôs not mine.

A tough and unenjoyable puzzle for me, unfortunately.
Just too many US trivia references - I was trying to fit ‚Äúreelects Truman‚Äù in, for instance.
Obviously you‚Äôre not going to know everything but the crosses were too obscure to help.
I appreciate the NYT is a US publication, but with the way it markets its subscriptions so aggressively internationally, perhaps a bit of consideration for its global crossword fans would be appreciated.

Bottom right took for ever ‚Ä¶

Suitable for USAians only. 

Some times it doesn‚Äôt click. 

Never mind.

Not been around much this week, too many of my entirely innocent and purely crossword related posts have not appeared. I feel like I‚Äôm being shunned at a polite dinner party. 

Here goes: that was the hardest grid I‚Äôve filled in a long time, sadly not in a ‚Äòwow, that was tough but fabulous‚Äô way. Far too many specific US references to make this even halfway possible. I completely accept that‚Äôs a perfectly reasonable theme for the NYT, being an American publication. But it stonewalled me.

Well done Mr Schlossberg on an entertaining and unusual theme, I‚Äôm only sorry I wasn‚Äôt able to appreciate it.

For those kind posters who‚Äôve asked me about my Alpacas‚Äôs; I tried several times to respond (see my first paragraph). They‚Äôre beautiful and settling in nicely. Not too keen on the dogs so we‚Äôre keeping them well away, with one closely monitored visit a day over the fence so they can get used to each other.

Fingers crossed this posts.

27 A was the best birthday gift I have ever received.  In a dream universe, I would get a similar gift for my 70th this August.

Being a news junkie definitely gave me a leg up today.  Automatically entering WALL STreet as the beginning for 64 A slowed me down in that section at first, but getting the joke at 
43 D put me on the right path.

Crossing 64 A with 69 D was a nice touch.

That Post headline took a while...geez, talk about a grisly bare.

Sorry.
Hardest Sunday crossword in a long while! A real challenge from start to finish. Just wish it didn‚Äôt have to be on the one Sunday of the year that we lose an hour! üôÉ

What I loved about this theme was that it was not a one-trick pony.  It had dimension:
‚Ä¢	The riddle-cracking fun of guessing those long answers with as few crosses as possible.
‚Ä¢	Most of its answers evoked images of the headlined events, where I paused to relive what I remembered.
‚Ä¢	The headlines that were funny WERE funny to me, filling me with smiles. 
‚Ä¢	The one headline that was unfamiliar was a worthy TIL.

So, the theme was more an experience rather than simply a figure-it-out.  

Plus, some lovely sparks.  The gorgeous APOCRYPHA.  Being misdirected by [Drink after a race, say] for HYDRATE, where I was seeing ‚Äúdrink‚Äù as a noun.  That tiny 4x4 section in the upper SE rife with schwa enders AROMA, EMMA, MAMA, and a backward DATA.  And finally, two uber-clever clues: [Where people typically go to the mat] for PORCH, and [They‚Äôre known to open with some jokes], for APRILS.

Very fond of what the box offered today; thumbs raised high.  Thank you greatly for this, Michael!

When I work on a puzzle sometimes even if I‚Äôve gotten an answer on a cross, I have to look it up because I have no idea what it means. Then I learn a new word. Which is how I know aglet and gar etc. For me, that is part of the fun.
Loved it! History, fun headlines, nice and straightforward. When a puzzle opens with a long-gone First Lady's name, I know I'm going to like it.

For ‚Äústereotypically red headwear‚Äù, I was sure that was going to be‚Ä¶ something contemporary, let‚Äôs say.  

Maybe that was the idea?

For a news fiend like me, the puzzle was a delight. However the clues around the best headline (NY Post 1983) were too arcane for me to get to it. 

Swathi

I found this to be relatively stress-free, because I'm old enough to remember some of these headlines. It was easy to deduce others by the dates, e.g TITANIC, WALL ST.

The one that held me up for a while was one that I remembered without seeing any of the crossings. For some weird reason, I instantly knew that it was going to be TO NY DROP DEAD. That was such an iconic headline, especially to a New Yorker. Problem was, I couldn't remember who said it! And that was even after I got the D from FORD. Eventually I got it from one of the crosses. 

It's understandable that the foreign solvers would have had a lot of trouble with this, but I, usually the contrarian here, really enjoyed it.

Clever puzzle - just well above my pay grade. Had to cheat some to get through it. No big deal. Appropriate puzzle find today: a Sunday from March 12, 1995 by Charles M. Deber with the title "Times Past." All of the theme clues were of the same format. One example: "Headline of #36,683 (Ju1y 1, 1958)" And the answer was: ALASKATOJOINUNION Some other theme answers - also just with the date of the headline as clues: FIRESINCHICAGO ALLIEDARMIESLAND TWOGERMANYSUNITE STOCKSCOLLAPSE PROHIBITIONREPEAL SHERMANSMARCH TITANICSINKS Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=3/12/1995&g=74&d=D I'll shut up now. ...

This was fun. The dates gave away almost all of the headlines for me, but it took a while to get the DROPDEAD one. For some reason, I recalled it as PREZTOCITY, so that took an adjustment.

Got a lot filled in on my first pass, including CANOODLE for "Fool around", which obviously had to go.

Great start to what may be a slow Sunday.

Thanks!
All smooth and fun until southeast corner..a couple of crosses were just naticks for me. And having pastor instead of parson didn't help!

Loved, loved this fun Sunday! TIL about SAL soda, and now know more than desirable about taxidermy.üò≥ If you watched Phineas and Ferb, you‚Äôll never forget the AGLET. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r_DuY0CQUz4

Aw, come on.
This was a cinch.

Except for the 17 spots where it wasn‚Äôt.
(Hubby *necessary* FTW.)

Fan. Tas. Tic.

And since y‚Äôall helped me 
free myself of my deja vu pet peeve, 

can you help me with the use/misuse (?)
of AW?

Awe, what a cute baby!
Awe, I love it!

I appreciate that it *could* be an expression
of awe at the cuteness, but isn‚Äôt it just, um, wrong?

Aw, that puppy is adorable!

Aw, come on.
Help CC out..?

For *your* baby name, just combine your last two crossing answers in today‚Äôs puzzle. Call me ‚ÄúOHME EMMA‚Äù.
Definitely not as popular as Plummette.

Quite the slog. Seemed like it came from the (easier side of the) archives, lots of old references. Fun to do, if you‚Äôre patient.

Well I've solved all the headlines and have to say I was a bit surprised by the last one, which at first did not seem to match the gravitas of all the others.  But I guess considering the source (Post) and the era (80's) it does fit.  

Still stuck in many places so will likely chip away at this one later today.
Wicked fun puzzle, even the tough spots. Does it make me feel old that I knew all but two headlines in a snap? You bet! Very clever and well thought out.
Immeasurably disappointed that 8A doesn't solve to "MNOP". You were on the cusp of greatness, Mr. Schlossberg. You were so close.
Insanely difficult. No words.

My favorite puzzle so far this year - more puzzles from history nerds, please!! Had never heard of the the last headline - had fun looking it up and refreshing my memory about the others. And TWIGS and LAYS AN EGG give me the opportunity to remark that Cornell's Red-tailed Hawks webcam is back online! We are hoping for some eggs later this month. Right now you will mostly just see the nest (affectionately named "Mount Stickmore") but fingers crossed! https://www.allaboutbirds.org/cams/red-tailed-hawks/#
Had to give up an 83-day streak. Still baffled by some answers, quite a few naticks, too much obscure US trivia. Hardest puzzle in quite a while.
As a non-American born in 1994 (who never took to history..)‚Ä¶.. this one hurt.

For 44 down, I went through the list of Late Show band leaders. Doc Severinson? Kevin Eubanks? At least Questlove had the right number of letters. Even with several crosses I had a hard time coming up with TOSCANINI because I had never imagined NBC had an actual symphony orchestra. Definitely a fun puzzle. 

The column says "But Mr. Ford definitely blamed it for costing him the presidential nomination in 1976." I am pretty sure Ford won the Republican presidential nomination but lost the election.
This puzzle is beyond unfair. The last 2 headlines are too obscure and cross with random proper nouns and terrible riddles. An unbalanced slog fest.
Needed IMDb a lot for this. Hate having to look that stuff up, but the other directions weren‚Äôt helpful.

I remember seeing the Ford Tells City Drop Dead headline. I was so furious. 

I remember doing a crossword puzzle (not in the Times) on April 1st and it drove me crazy. Each way the answers seemed easy but they did not cross with one another. So the next day I looked at the answers and I thought my brain took a hike. Everything looked so weird. Somehow, I looked at the date and realized that the puzzle was on April Fools Day--all the answers were backward!

Finally, great stumper on 8 across. I swear I put in MNOP and that didn't cross with anything. LOL. Then I caught on. I loved it.

I stood up and cheered when I finished this puzzle. And then I realized I was by myself, and Mr. Schlossberg could not see me. I knew every one of those headlines and enjoyed looking at the dates and trying to remember what was going on at that moment.
I loved this one. A bit longer than my average Sunday. Props to the constructor for getting AGLET and EYELET in the same puzzle.

Um.....  I did know (or even live through) a couple of the headline events.  The puzzle was challenging thanks to tricky crosses, and then, well...  I got to the final headline and the SE corner. 
I was not aware of this momentous occurrence.  
What to say?

Thanks for the uplifting message?
Great reminder of significant events?
What a swell trip down Memory Lane?
or...Have you lost your minds?

Sigh.
You wait all week for a Sunday puzzle, and then THIS comes along. Where are my rebuses? Where are my mutilated and bent solution words?
Got the theme with TITANIC SINKS, by which time it was obvious that, as a foreigner, I was going nowhere with either the fill or the theme.
Killed it with Reveal, spent a bit of time snorting incredulously at some of the answers, and then flounced off to the archives.
There's always next week, I suppose...
Pretty tough, and I can see how it would be quite opaque to younger folks. Ford to City was my breakthrough, remember that moment very well. Good Sunday puzzle, I approve.
For " Wrap one's head around," I briefly considered EAT.

There is no excuse for this abominable construction.
Natick after Natick crossing through ridiculous themed answers. I will say the first 3 headlines were reasonable.
91A is impossible to put together without actually knowing this headline from 50 years ago.
Recycled clues, random poorly placed proper nouns (especially 110D), and terrible riddles.
Truly an unbalanced slog fest.
Okay seriously, if obscurely, who here wouldn't want to see Louis Malle's "My Dinner With Andrzej"?

Fantastic crossword.
Ok, I only got the first 2 headlines, and simply revealed the others when I knew I couldn't ever guess them. 

I've never heard of FOR THE WIN and couldn't guess I DECLARE or AETNA, which held up that corner, but the rest wasn't too bad, with lots of predicting/guessing!

How does ATAD mean slightly, please?
too hard

Where was the wordplay?  I wait all week for a clever Sunday and the theme involved trivia, not actual wordplay.

A huge disappointment, and a slog.  I solved it, but I did not enjoy doing so.

A headline from the LA Times, last year:

"Lego thefts across Southern California leave police trying to piece together clues"

I was waiting to see this headline, which didn‚Äôt appear, so I‚Äôm sharing it: Hell Freezes Over, Oct. 21, 2004, Daily News Sports.
(A calamity for my beloved Yankees.)
Woof. I had to Google a couple things, struggled hard, hugged the cat for moral support, and now I'm going to rest. A rough ride, but so it goes.
Super fun Sunday puzzle, so didn‚Äôt miss a rebus .
As a former reporter (Can't those copy editors ever write a headline that matches my story?) and copy editor (When will the reporters ever learn to write?) I like this puzzle.

I don‚Äôt know why it is but I usually spring back and fall forward. Which makes me two hours behind, now. The times they are a-changing! 

Fun puzzle.
I'm older so was familiar with all these headlines, maybe this theme is payback for all the thousands of celebrities and rappers younger solvers might know, but I have never heard of.

Took me a long time but I enjoyed the theme. The London 1912 clue (25A) was the only one where I had a good idea what the subject might be, but It was fun finding out the answers to the others (especially the two-part one, lol).

However 111A was my finest hour. I only knew LOLLYGAG because it come up as one of the possible answers on a Spelling Bee ages ago. I'd never heard of it before but the word stuck in my head and today I got a chance to use it! What a great word.

Titanic sinks and Nixon resigns are famous events. They aren't very special headlines.

And 'oared'? More than a little forced.

Wow my streak of 770 nearly broken by that messy messy middle section - I do love a tricky puzzle but one that needs cleverness to solve as opposed to slogging it out to figure out random names and naticks. 

I do love reading the last headline though whenever it comes my way. 

And the now classic: ‚Äúwhen an eel climbs a ramp to eat a squid from a clamp, that‚Äôs a moray‚Äù
Tortured words such as OARED lessened my enjoyment of this one.

Pretty brutal. Looks like I wasn't alone finding that middle section a real slog. I'm OK not knowing anything about golf - it evens out since I probably get more of the football and baseball references than some - but I will never ever get the obsession with conductors. And crossing proper nouns is just poor form.

I hope Mr. Schlossberg is encouraged by the yaysayers and doesn't dwell on the naysayers.  Images of the newspapers bearing these headlines are themselves iconic - well worth a Google image search for the unfamiliar.  Sometimes trivia is its own reward - the next time one of them comes up on trivia night you may be glad you solved it.  I enjoyed filling out those headlines straightaway, and was delighted to tease out the kicker at 113-/115-Across that didn't come readily.  Kudos!
booooooo
The dates were the keys here! An excellent theme and reminds me of Bogart's famous line from Deadline - USA: "It's the press, baby! The press! And there's nothing you can do about it. Nothing!"

"Nickname" has the same number of letters as AL CAPONE.... just saying...

Most of these headlines were before my time so I was happy I actually knew some of them. I breezed through the top half of the puzzle, but hit a wall at 91A.

I struggled mightily in the bottom section, filling in answers only to delete them when they were clearly wrong. I was so surprised to hear the happy music when I filled in my last answer (ECCE) that I physically startled. I'm done? OH ME!

I love history and trivia, so this was fun--and pretty fast except for that middle section....

The last square I filled in was the V in 58D, only because it was the only thing I could think of for the cross.

I won't admit how long it took me to make sense of it....

I loved this puzzle. Seeing the clues for the publishing dates immediately spurred the brain to think of what happened in those months and years. If you thought you knew what the historical event being referred to was, you still had to figure out the wording and spelling of the headline.
1948 was especially fun - it was a big year, and the publishing reference could have been an event in India, Czechoslovakia, or Palestine among others. No way to know what the event was until a few letters got filled in via crosses. 
I'm sure there will be some haters and I've hated puzzles in the past myself, but this one sat just right in my experience, with good cluing that made for fairly brisk fills.
Great theme undone by some tortured clueing. A frustrating slog for me.

Seems like a lot people here found this quite manageable. 

I solved it unaided, but it took around 1 hour 45 minutes.

I found it incredibly difficult with the crossing of obscure clues and names, but that may just be me.

While it felt okay to get the gold star, for me, this was more of a workout than I really wanted.

No demands or complaints, I know a lot of you cruise through this sort of thing. Just giving the NYT team some anecdotal feedback.
All I can say is AWCOMEON.

I know this will not last, but giving it a shot.

@Alex 
I'm legitimately surprised that so many people had trouble with this puzzle. I'd call it a little over medium difficulty.

As to the references, most of them were of well-known people and occurrences. (NIXON RESIGNS and TITANIC SINKS--we've all seen those movies, right?) The ones that weren't well-known I could guess from the crosses (IDA McKinley, Joe TYNAN).

My rule of thumb for people I haven't heard of is, "That's a name!" Even though I didn't know of the Alan Alda film, I looked at the crosses and thought: "TYNAN, that's a name! I'll put it in." Sometimes I'll leave a space blank: "Is he SNEED or SNEAD? I'll leave that fourth space blank."

That said, there was little in the puzzle I was unfamiliar with (the crossing of Mr. SNEAD and SAL being my undoing). In order to be good at crossword puzzles, you need a head for trivia. It might be possible to avoid trivia in the Mini, but in a 21x21 Sunday grid it's impossible. I suggest reading, watching, and listening as widely as you can to up your crossword game. Get out of your comfort zone: if you love classical, listen to rap, or vice versa. Pick up a novel in a genre you don't like. If you've never played a video game, now's the time to start--they have improved just a little since the days of Pong.

In short: be curious.
